G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Complaint is properly before the Boston Municipal Court, Roxbury Division, pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, § 3, because it concerns a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment related to rental housing located in Roxbury, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1 and 8.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court under G.L. c. 223, §§ 1 and 8, as the acts and omissions giving rise to Plaintiff’s claims occurred in Roxbury, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 18.proposition: Defendant stated this was due to Plaintiff’s late rent in October 2025; however, Plaintiff believes this decision was made in retaliation for complaining about the water intrusion and calling housing authorities, in violation of G.L. c. 186, § 18.

**G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14**.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord has an obligation to provide their tenant with the quiet enjoyment of their rental property, as guaranteed by **G.L. c. 186, § 14**.

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7 127L.proposition: Injunctive relief requiring Defendant to remedy the water intrusion pursuant to G.L. c. 111, § 127L;

Darman v. Dunderdale, 362 Mass. 633 (197.proposition: Darman v. Dunderdale, 362 Mass. 633 (1972) – Tenant entitled to quiet enjoyment without substantial interference.
Darman v. Dunderdale, 362 Mass. 633 (197.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns registration of title and whether neighboring landowners hold easements or rights of way over the petitioner’s land. It does not involve a landlord-tenant relationship, the covenant of quiet enjoyment, or any discussion of a tenant’s entitlement to be free from substantial interference. Accordingly, citing this case for a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment is inaccurate and out of context.
Darman v. Dunderdale, 362 Mass. 633 (197.relevant_excerpt: "We conclude that the respondents have no easement or right of way over the petitioner’s land. There was no error in the Land Court judge’s rulings."

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) – Landlord’s failure to address water intrusion constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely treats repeated water/sewage intrusion as interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and under the implied covenant. The court holds that Gem is liable under § 14 because, by failing to maintain watertight conditions and allowing repeated flooding, it “interfered with” Solomon’s quiet enjoyment; it describes the water as a preventable condition the landlord had a duty to correct. Although the quiet-enjoyment damages award is later vacated as duplicative, the liability holding that such flooding constitutes interference with quiet enjoyment remains intact.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The water in Solomon’s apartment was a preventable situation, and one that Gem had a duty to prevent. See 105 Code Mass. Regs. 410.500; Crowell v. McCaffrey, 377 Mass. 443 (1979); Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973). The jury found in answer to a special question… that the water interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment of her apartment. Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14… [Gem] violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).proposition: Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991) – Treble damages under G.L. c. 186, § 14, for willful landlord conduct.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).support_reasoning: The opinion is about treble damages under G.L. c. 93A, not treble damages under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The court affirms an award of treble damages under c. 93A for intentional infliction of emotional distress and breach of the warranty of habitability, and separately discusses c. 186 only as to retaliation (c. 186, § 18) and quiet enjoyment, without addressing § 14’s treble-damages remedy or setting any standard for “willful” conduct under that section. Thus, it does not support the specific proposition that it interprets or applies treble damages under G.L. c. 186, § 14 for willful landlord conduct.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).relevant_excerpt:
The judge then added both base awards, trebled the total, and subtracted rent withheld by Gonzalez. The judge later added to this award, an award of attorneys' fees and costs.
...
We conclude that, in appropriate circumstances, tenants may recover multiple damages for the intentional infliction of emotional distress under c. 93A.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977) – Landlord liable for substantial interferences caused by failure to act.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The court held that a landlord can be liable for a constructive eviction and breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment where substantial interference with tenants’ use (here, pervasive bar noise) was the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted, and where the landlord had the right and ability to control the condition but did not effectively abate it. The opinion expressly rejects a strict malfeasance/nonfeasance distinction in such circumstances, making it clear that failure to act to correct known, controllable substantial interferences can result in landlord liability.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent… To the extent that our opinions suggest a distinction between nonfeasance… and malfeasance… we decline to perpetuate that distinction where the landlord creates a situation and has the right to control the objectionable conditions.”

Warsame v. Miller, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 52.raw_text: Warsame v. Miller, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 52 (2010)
Warsame v. Miller, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 52.proposition: Warsame v. Miller, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 52 (2010) – Retaliation for tenant complaints violates quiet enjoyment covenant.
Warsame v. Miller, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 52.support_reasoning: The opinion in Warsame v. Miller (actually Santiago v. Alba/Windsor as excerpted) is a real estate/title and mortgage foreclosure case. It analyzes ownership, mortgage foreclosure by peaceable entry, and the effect on legal and equitable title; it does not address landlord‑tenant law, tenant complaints, retaliation, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Therefore it cannot be authority for the proposition that retaliation for tenant complaints violates the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Warsame v. Miller, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 52.relevant_excerpt: Application of those basic principles means that on February 16,1996, when Alba purported to assign the mortgage to Sylvan, there simply was no mortgage to assign. More than three years had passed since Alba filed the certificate of peaceable entry. The equity of redemption was gone and with it the mortgage. At that point, Alba owned the property in fee.

Dolores v. Gustafson, 386 Mass. 1007 (19.proposition: Dolores v. Gustafson, 386 Mass. 1007 (1982) – Remedies in retaliation and substantial interference cases under G.L. c. 186.
Dolores v. Gustafson, 386 Mass. 1007 (19.case_name: Deluca v. Chief Administrative Justice of Trial Court
Dolores v. Gustafson, 386 Mass. 1007 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the discharge of court officers due to budgetary constraints and is dismissed as moot after the plaintiffs are rehired. It does not interpret G.L. c. 186, does not involve landlord-tenant law, retaliation, or substantial interference, and contains no discussion of remedies under that chapter. Citing this case for remedies in retaliation and substantial interference cases under G.L. c. 186 is inaccurate.
Dolores v. Gustafson, 386 Mass. 1007 (19.relevant_excerpt: Because the plaintiffs have now resumed their employment, a declaration of this court would not have an immediate impact on their employment rights. The plaintiffs now assert that they sustained a loss of employment benefits including *1008 approximately three months’ pay. In their complaint, however, they sought only injunctive relief and a declaration that the action and order of the Chief Administrative Justice was unlawful. They made no claim for damages based on loss of pay. The questions raised by the complaint have become moot.

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 185 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 185 (1973) – Landlord’s obligations under Massachusetts State Sanitary Code.
